Title: Jimmy Carter's funeral services begin in Washington, D.C., today
Description: The next stop in former President Jimmy Carter's six days of funeral services is Washington, D.C., where he will lie in state in the U.S. Capitol through Thursday morning. (Image credit: Jon Cherry)

Title: How ISIS is adapting its tactics to survive
Description: Is ISIS having a resurgence? NPR's A Martinez talks to Aaron David Miller, senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, about how ISIS is adapting its tactics to survive.

Title: In 2007 interview, Jimmy Carter discusses what he faced after losing reelection
Description: Hear excerpts from a 2007 NPR interview with former President Jimmy Carter talking about the stark question he faced after failing to win reelection: what to do with the rest of his life.

Title: Syria's interim government faces a new, serious challenge — bread lines
Description: Bread lines have become a feature of the new Syria, posing a critical challenge to the country's rebel rulers who ousted President Bashar al-Assad last month.

Title: Growing number of Colombians are fighting — and dying — in conflicts around the world
Description: More and more former members of Colombia's armed forces are fighting and dying as mercenaries around the world.

Title: Virginia elections could determine if Democrats hold slim majority in Legislature
Description: Special elections in Virginia could decide whether Democrats maintain their control of the Legislature as the commonwealth heads into a governor's race this fall.

Title: Hamas and Israel are negotiating the release of hostages from Gaza
Description: Israel and Hamas are eyeing a hostage release and ceasefire deal before Donald Trump's inauguration.

Title: Former adviser and analyst discusses why key committee was split on U.S. Steel deal
Description: Why was the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States split on allowing or blocking Nippon Steel from buying U.S. Steel? NPR's Michel Martin asks one of the committee's former advisers.

Title: Ski patrollers strike at Utah's Park City Mountain resort
Description: Ski-industry giant Vail resorts is struggling with a strike by ski patrollers at Park City Mountain resort in Utah, their biggest property. Skiers are complaining about delays and unsafe conditions.

Title: Morning Edition colleagues share snow-day traditions
Description: With much of the central and eastern U.S. blanketed with snow, our Morning Edition colleagues share a few beloved snow day traditions.

Title: Minneapolis, DOJ agree on police reforms in wake of George Floyd murder
Description: The city of Minneapolis and the U.S. Department of Justice have agreed on a consent decree which calls for the Minneapolis Police Department to make extensive reforms. The agreement comes five years after the death of George Floyd caused protests around the city and the world.

Title: U.K. leader Starmer slams 'lies and misinformation' after attacks from Elon Musk
Description: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Monday condemned 'lies and misinformation' that he said are undermining U.K. democracy, in response to a barrage of attacks on his government from Elon Musk. (Image credit: Leon Neal/AP)

Title: Minneapolis agrees to overhaul police training and policies following Floyd murder
Description: The Minneapolis City Council on Monday approved an agreement with the federal government to overhaul the city's police training and use-of-force policies in the wake of the murder of George Floyd. (Image credit: Jeff Wheeler/AP)

Title: Rudy Giuliani is held in contempt of court in $148 million defamation case
Description: Rudy Giuliani was found in contempt of court for failing to properly respond to requests for information as he turned over assets to satisfy a defamation ruling granted to two Georgia poll workers. (Image credit: Adam Gray)

Title: The National Zoo's giant pandas make the most of DC's snow
Description: The two giant pandas were seen on camera playing around in the snowfall that blanketed much of the Midwest and mid-Atlantic on Monday. (Image credit: National Zoo)

Title: First bird flu death reported in the U.S., according to the CDC
Description: Health officials in Louisiana say a person there has died after catching bird flu. This marks the first reported death in the U.S. from the virus during the current outbreak. (Image credit: Callista Images)

Title: Elon Musk has been trolling British politicians, stirring anger and concern
Description: Fixated on a UK sex abuse scandal from 15 years ago, Elon Musk has been trolling British officials, prompting a rebuke from the prime minister and worry over what this portends for U.S. policy.

Title: It will now cost up to $9 to drive into New York City
Description: Motorists driving into many parts of Manhattan will now pay as much as $9, as part of a new congestion pricing plan to eliminate traffic and pay for improvements to mass transit.

Title: In Syria, a once-privileged Muslim sect is now targeted and afraid
Description: Alawites in Syria are facing a violent backlash, stoking fears of wider sectarian instability in a divided Syria after the fall of the Assad regime.

Title: Pentagon agrees to settle historic lawsuit with LGBTQ+ veterans over discharge status
Description: The Pentagon has agreed to settle a class action lawsuit involving about 35,000 LGBTQ+ veterans that will help them get benefits like health care and disability. (Image credit: Daniel Slim)

Title: 32 dolphins have died since an oil spill near southern Russia, experts say
Description: A dolphin rescue center said most of the dead dolphins were from the endangered Azov species. (Image credit: Krasnodar Gov. Veniamin Kondraty)

Description: Millions of Americans are under weather advisories today as a winter storm blasts through the middle of the country.

Title: What may be next after a federal court struck down the FCC's net neutrality rules
Description: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Stanford Law Professor Barbara van Schewick about a federal court's decision to strike down the Biden administration's net neutrality protections.

Title: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will step down once his party has a new leader
Description: Under pressure from voters and his own members of parliament, Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced Monday that he will step down once his Liberal Party names a sucessor.

Title: Biden visits New Orleans after Jan. 1 attack
Description: President Joe Biden will travel to New Orleans on Monday and attend a prayer service for the 14 victims of the New Year's Day attack.

Title: The Epicenter of the COVID Outbreak Five Years Later
Description: We go to the city were there the COVID-19 global pandemic started five years ago, Wuhan, China. We find that security is still tight and trauma is still pervasive. We look at what has changed— and what hasn't— since the 'mysterious illness' first emerged.

Title: U.S. transfers 11 Yemeni prisoners from Guantánamo to Oman
Description: The Biden administration's move leaves just 15 detainees at the U.S. military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. Oman will help resettle the men and provide security monitoring. (Image credit: Thomas Watkins)

Title: Hamas and Israel are negotiating the release of 34 hostages from Gaza
Description: The deal would secure release of a third of the approximately 100 hostages who remain in Gaza, including two dual U.S.-Israeli nationals. In return, Israel would release some Palestinian prisoners. (Image credit: Amir Levy/Getty Images)

Title: Millions of public workers are set to get higher Social Security benefits. Here's why
Description: Public service workers including some teachers, firefighters, police officers may soon see their Social Security payments increase by hundreds of dollars. (Image credit: Kent Nishimura)

Title: Lessons from self-inflicted blows to democracy in South Korea and the U.S.
Description: The brief declaration of martial law in South Korea last month has drawn comparisons to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. The attempted power grabs could hold lessons for other democracies. (Image credit: Anthony Wallace)

Title: Canada's Justin Trudeau says he will resign as party leader and prime minister
Description: Trudeau's decision after almost a decade in power sets the stage for a succession fight to select a new prime minister. (Image credit: Dave Chan)

Title: Photos: See the impact a major winter storm is having on U.S.
Description: Winter storm warnings have ben declared from Illinois to New Jersey. And some areas will get a lot of snow. They will also get freezing rain and ice, blustery winds and frigid temperatures. (Image credit: Joshua A. Bickel)

Title: How Jan. 6 will be different this year. And, who took home a Golden Globe award
Description: Today, four years since the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, President-elect Donald Trump's victory is scheduled to be certified by Congress. And, the big wins and surprises at the 82nd Golden Globes. (Image credit: Brendan Smialowski/Pool)

Description: President Joe Biden is moving to ban new offshore oil and gas drilling in most U.S. coastal waters, an effort to block possible action by the incoming Trump administration to expand offshore drilling. (Image credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta)

Title: Pictures of Odesa, as it tangles with a complex web of Russian and Ukrainian heritage

Description: Nearly 2 million tourists visit the U.S. Capitol each year and learn about the building's art and history. What they don't hear on official tours is what happened on Jan. 6, 2021.

Description: Festival season starts in New Orleans today with the first Mardi Gras parade as people there are still processing last week's terror attack in the French Quarter.

Description: Locals in Syria's Golan Heights told NPR that they fear a recent Israeli military operation in the area could be a land grab. Israel says the move is necessary to secure its borders.

Description: Former Capitol Police officer Aquilino Gonell was repeatedly assaulted during the Jan. 6, 2021 riot. Since Donald Trump's reelection, he says he feels 'betrayed.'

Description: The man who crashed a truck through the French Quarter in New Orleans killing 14 people, visited the city twice before the attack. Authorities say the Texas native also went to Egypt and Canada.

Description: A Capitol Police officer assaulted during the Jan. 6 riot says he feels 'betrayed,' CNN is in court Monday fighting a defamation lawsuit, and we take a look at the 2025 Golden Globe winners.

Title: Indonesia launches free meals program to fight stunting
Description: Indonesia's new government started an ambitious project to feed nearly 90 million children and pregnant women to fight malnutrition and stunting, as critics question whether the program is affordable. (Image credit: Dita Alangkara)

Description: The FBI says the man who allegedly carried out the New Year's Day attack visited the city in October and November, and recorded video of the area he aimed to target using 'smart glasses.' (Image credit: Gerald Herbert)

Description: Following the New Year's Day truck attack in New Orleans, people who live in the French Quarter discuss what's ahead for them and their neighborhood.

Title: Venezuela opposition leader Edmundo González embarks on international tour
Description: González, who the United States recognized as the winner of last year's presidential election in Venezuela, kicked off an international tour on Saturday that will take him to Washington. (Image credit: Natacha Pisarenko)

Title: South Korean protesters brave cold to demand Yoon's ouster as detention deadline looms
Description: South Koreans rallied overnight near the residence of impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol calling for his arrest, as authorities prepared to renew their efforts to detain him. (Image credit: Ahn Young-joon)

In Lebanon, the Litani River demarcates identity — and war

Title: Services honoring former president Jimmy Carter begin today in Georgia

Jurassic footprints are discovered on a 'dinosaur highway' in southern England
Description: The 166-million-year-old footprint tracks, found at a quarry in southern England, mark one of the largest discoveries in decades.

Title: A storm will bring heavy snow and dangerous ice from the Plains to the East Coast
Description: This weekend's storm is expected to impact 62 million Americans through Monday. Heavy snow, ice, rain and severe thunderstorms will be unleashed from the Plains to the East Coast. (Image credit: NWS Weather Prediction Center)

Description: The FBI is investigating the Jan. 1 attack in New Orleans as an act of terrorism while the motivation for the Jan 1. truck explosion in Las Vegas is still unclear but appears to be mental illness.

Title: House and Senate majority leaders set the agenda for early weeks of a new Congress
Description: The new Republican majorities in the House and Senate plan to move border legislation and cabinet confirmations first, with tax bills coming later this year.

Description: A motorcade with the body of Pres. Jimmy Carter travels to his hometown of Plains, Ga., and then on to Atlanta Saturday.

Title: Vehicular attacks are not new. But preventing them has been a big challenge
Description: For decades, individuals and terrorist groups have used vehicles to carry out deadly attacks. But installing safeguards hasn't always been successful. (Image credit: Jack Brook)

Title: Seeking to heal the country, Jimmy Carter pardoned men who evaded the Vietnam War draft
Description: The pardon was one of the defining presidential moments for Jimmy Carter, who died Dec. 29 at the age of 100. The move was pilloried by members of the military and conservative politicians.

Title: Funeral services for former President Jimmy Carter start today in Georgia
Description: The first day of memorial services for former President Jimmy Carter begins today in his hometown of Plains, Ga., and will include stops at the Georgia State Capitol and the Carter Center in Atlanta. (Image credit: Alex Wroblewski)

Title: Japanese woman who was the world's oldest person at 116 has died
Description: Tomiko Itooka, a Japanese woman who was the world's oldest person according to Guinness World Records, has died, an Ashiya city official said Saturday. She was 116. (Image credit: AP)

Title: The potato-shaped loophole in free trade
Description: Ever since free trade opened up between the US and Mexico in the 1990s, trillions of dollars of goods have been going back and forth between the two countries, from cars to strawberries to MRI machines to underwear. But one major exception has been fresh American potatoes.Today on the show, we tell the trade saga of the American potato. For more than 25 years, there was a place that American potatoes could not go to freely. A place that the entire American potato industry was desperate to access. A vast, untapped market: Mexico.But standing in their way – the Mexican potato lobby and a trade loophole.This episode was hosted by Erika Beras and Jeff Guo. It was produced by Willa Rubin and edited by Meg Cramer. It was fact-checked by Sierra Juarez. Engineering by C...

Title: The soldier who died in Cybertruck explosion wrote it was intended as a 'wakeup call'
Description: Matthew Livelsberger, a 37-year-old Green Beret from Colorado, also wrote in a note that he needed to 'cleanse my mind' of the lives lost of people he knew and 'the burden of the lives I took.' (Image credit: Bizuayehu Tesfaye)

Title: New Orleans moves forward after New Year's Day attack
Description: In New Orleans, it's been several days since the New Year's Day truck attack in the French Quarter. As residents and tourists grapple with what happened, people are also trying to get back to normal.

Title: Trump will be sentenced Jan. 10 in New York case, days before his inauguration
Description: The decision also comes after the judge in the case ruled last month that Trump isn't immune from his conviction. (Image credit: Rebecca Noble)

Title: Biden made diversifying the federal bench a top priority. Here's a look at his legacy
Description: President Biden's judicial picks have included the first Black woman to the U.S. Supreme Court, women of color to federal appeals courts and openly LGBTQ judges to serve on the federal bench. (Image credit: Shawn Thew)

Title: Study: Cash handouts have a dramatic impact on the deadliest infectious disease
Description: A program in Brazil that give a monthly cash sum to families living in poverty has an unexpected — and welcome result. A new study shows that it is dramatically reducing tuberculosis rates. (Image credit: Stefano Figalo/Brazil Photos/LightRocket via Getty Images)

Description: Officials have not yet released the names of the 14 people killed in the New Orleans New Year's Day truck attack, but their families and friends have started sharing their stories. (Image credit: Jack Brook)

Title: The U.S. Surgeon General wants cancer warnings on alcohol. Here's why
Description: Drinking alcohol raises the risk of developing seven types of cancer, according to a new advisory from U.S. Surgeon General Vivek Murthy. (Image credit: David J. Phillip)

Description: Authorities in New Orleans and Texas are piecing together why a man drove a pick-up truck down Bourbon Street on New Year's Day -- killing 14 and injuring dozens of others.

Title: Assessing the Damage at Lebanon's Historical Sites
Description: Part of a Crusader castle collapsed. An 18th century minaret toppled. Church mosaics burned. Israeli airstrikes have damaged priceless antiquities across Lebanon & Syria during it's war with Hezbollah. With a ceasefire now in place, archaeologists are trying to assess damage to UNESCO World Heritage Sites. We visit some.

Title: 2 dead and 18 injured in Southern California plane crash
Description: Two people died and 18 were injured Thursday when a small plane crashed through the roof of a furniture manufacturing building in Southern California, police said. (Image credit: Jeff Gritchen/AP)

Title: Photos: Bourbon Street reopens in New Orleans after truck attack

Title: Still on the hunt, the FBI shares new details about pipe bombs placed ahead of Jan. 6
Description: Officials are still trying to identify the person who placed bombs outside of the Democratic National Committee and the Republican National Committee offices in 2021. Now they have fresh details. (Image credit: FBI)

Title: Italy summons Iranian ambassador to demand release of journalist Cecilia Sala
Description: On Thursday in Rome, Italy's foreign ministry summoned the Iranian ambassador, demanding the immediate release of Italian reporter Cecilia Sala from Iran's notorious Evin prison.

Title: The oldest living Olympic medal winner, Ágnes Keleti, has died at age 103
Description: Keleti, who was also a Holocaust survivor, was hospitalized in critical condition with pneumonia on Dec. 25. She died Thursday morning in Budapest, the Hungarian state news agency reported. (Image credit: Laszlo Balogh)

Description: NPR's Andrew Limbong speaks with Michael McFaul, former U.S. Ambassador to Russia, about his recent piece in Foreign Affairs, 'How Trump Can End the War in Ukraine.'

Title: A father talks about losing his 18-year-old son in the New Orleans attack
Description: Kareem Badawi just finished his first semester at the University of Alabama, where was studying engineering. His father Belal Badawi says he was an 18 year old full of life.

Title: Ukrainian soldiers and shopkeepers hold on as Russia's siege of Pokrovsk tightens
Description: Ukrainian forces are fighting to hold on to the key city of Pokrovsk, in one of the fiercest battles in eastern Ukraine, but commanders admit the Russians have more troops and firepower. (Image credit: Anton Shtuka for NPR)

Title: FBI now says the suspect in the deadly New Orleans truck attack acted alone
Description: Shamsud-Din Jabbar, the driver of the pickup truck who plowed into a crowd in New Orleans on New Year's Day, killing at least 14 people, acted alone, the FBI said Thursday. (Image credit: George Walker IV)

Title: An 'Arctic outbreak' will send a chill through much of the U.S. Here's how to prepare

Description: In Damascus beauty parlors, Syrian women hope looking good will help them feel better about a future they fear. (Story aired on ATC on Dec. 31, 2024.)

Description: Las Vegas police are investigating any possible connections between the pickup truck attack in New Orleans and the Tesla Cybertruck which exploded in front of a Trump hotel in Las Vegas the same day.

Title: In the Country with the World's Worst Displacement Crisis: Sudan (Encore)
Description: Fighting between the Sudanese army and a paramilitary group have displaced some 12 million people in one of Africa's biggest countries. In a story we first brought you in October, our correspondent travels to Sudan and gives us a glimpse of the devastation the war has caused.

Title: An armed man kills at least 10 people in a shooting rampage in Montenegro
Description: At least 10 people, including two children, were killed and four others were seriously wounded Wednesday in a shooting rampage that followed a bar brawl in a western Montenegrin city, officials said. (Image credit: Risto Bozovic)

Title: Power is restored to nearly all of Puerto Rico after a major blackout
Description: Lights returned to households as well as to Puerto Rico's hospitals, water plants and sewage facilities after the massive outage that exposed the persistent electricity problems plaguing the island. (Image credit: Alejandro Granadillo)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: South Korea's parliament has voted to impeach the acting president, Israel strikes Yemen's capital following attacks by Houthi rebels, and Georgian protests continue in support of EU membership.

Title: Protests in Georgia continue as demonstrators rally in support for joining the EU
Description: On the eastern edge of the Black Sea, the Georgian president is refusing to step down, as demonstrations have gone on for weeks in support of Georgia joining the European Union.

Title: Israeli peace activists try to keep hope alive as Trump set to take office
Description: When his parents were killed in the Hamas-led on Israel October 7th, 2023, Moaz Inon put aside a successful tourism business career to focus on something else: peaceful co-existence with Palestinians. He has some ideas for the incoming Trump administration, which ignored Palestinians before.

Title: Turkey expected to play a major role in Syria following fall of the Assad regime
Description: Turkey is expected to play a major role as the new government takes over ruling Syria. Turkey had shown tacit support for groups fighting the Assad dictatorship.

Title: Number of journalists killed in conflict zones reaches 5-year high, according to RSF
Description: At least 54 journalists were killed covering conflict zones in 2024, according to Reporters Without Borders. NPR speaks with the head of RSF in the U.S., Clayton Weimers.

Title: Israel strikes Yemen's capital following attacks by Houthi rebels
Description: Israel bombed targets in Yemen's capital, killing at least two and injuring 11. The strikes come after a week of attacks by Houthi rebels, including a missile that penetrated Israel's air defenses.

Title: South Korea's opposition-controlled parliament votes to impeach acting president
Description: The impeachments of the country's president and then acting-president worsen the nation's political turmoil, deepen its economic uncertainty and hurt its international image. (Image credit: Choi Jae-koo/AP)

Title: Finland detains Russia-linked vessel over damaged undersea power cable in Baltic Sea
Description: Finnish authorities detained a ship linked to neighboring Russia that Finnish customs officials and the European Union's executive commission describe as part of Russia's shadow fleet of fuel tankers. (Image credit: Jussi Nukari/AP)

Title: What we know about the Azerbaijan Airlines jet crash that killed 38 people
Description: Investigators are trying to understand why an Azerbaijan Airlines jet heading to Russia crashed on Christmas, killing 38 people. The plane experienced an explosion before it went down in Kazakhstan.

Title: French authorities indict Telegram founder Pavel Durov on multiple charges
Description: Charges against the CEO of Telegram mark one of the few instances where the head of a major internet platform has been charged over alleged criminal failure to moderate what users do on its site.

Title: Governor of Damascus tells NPR about the new Syrian government's plans with Israel
Description: The governor of Damascus -- speaking for his direct boss Ahmed al-Sharaa, the newly installed leader of Syria -- says the government wants to facilitate cordial relations between Israel and Syria.

Title: Bird flu has killed 20 big cats including cougars at a U.S. wildlife sanctuary
Description: The sanctuary in Washington state said it was working with officials to determine the cause of the outbreak, which has killed over half of its cats in recent weeks. (Image credit: iStock)

Title: Israel strikes Houthi targets in Yemen's capital. WHO chief says he was nearby
Description: A round of Israeli airstrikes targeted the Houthi rebel-held capital and multiple ports. The head of the World Health Organization said the bombardment occurred as he prepared to board a flight. (Image credit: Osamah Abdulrahman)

Title: Manmohan Singh, India's prime minister from 2004 to 2014, has died
Description: Singh was known as the father of economic reforms in India. He served as finance minister in the early 1990s, and his policies then set India on the path of economic liberalization and globalization.

Title: Investigation begins into the cause of the Azerbaijan Airlines crash
Description: Azerbaijan observed a day of mourning for the victims of the plane crash that killed 38 people and left all 29 survivors injured as speculation mounted about a possible cause of the disaster. (Image credit: Azamat Sarsenbayev)

Title: Mourners mark 20 years since Indian Ocean tsunami that killed some 230,000 people
Description: Triggered by a 9.1 magnitude earthquake off the coast of the Indonesian island of Sumatra, the catastrophic event was the deadliest tsunami in recorded history. (Image credit: Wason Wanichakorn)

Title: Honda and Nissan consider a merger. And, Russia's Christmas Day attack in Ukraine
Description: Honda and Nissan are in talks over a merger as the auto industry sees two seismic changes. And, Russia violently attacked Ukraine's energy infrastructure on Christmas Day. (Image credit: Tomohiro Ohsumi)

Title: How to navigate gift returns and regifting this holiday season
Description: Etiquette experts weigh in on what to do with that ugly sweater you got for the holidays. (Image credit: Heather Khalifa)

Title: Israeli strike kills 5 Palestinian journalists in Gaza, officials say
Description: An Israeli strike killed five Palestinian journalists outside a hospital in the Gaza Strip overnight, according to the Health Ministry. The Israeli military said it had targeted a group of militants. (Image credit: Abdel Kareem Hana)

Title: Popeye, Tintin and more will enter the public domain in the new year
Description: The copyrights of thousands of 20th-century films, books, compositions and sound recordings expire on Jan. 1, making them free for anyone to share and adapt. Here are some of the highlights. (Image credit: Jacques Brinon)

Title: 100-plus cities in the U.S. banned homeless camping this year. But will it work?
Description: The burst of new laws follows a landmark Supreme Court ruling, and reflects public frustration with record-high homelessness. But advocates say fines and jail time will only make the problem worse. (Image credit: Jamie Kelter Davis)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Russia launches Christmas Day attacks on Ukrainian energy infrastructure, Honda and Nissan are in merger talks, and Nigeria's president defends economic reforms despite worsening crisis.

Title: Operation Lone Star takes toll on National Guard troops tasked with enforcing it
Description: Operation Lone Star is intended to deter illegal migration. It's also taking a toll on some of the Texas National Guardsmen tasked with enforcing it.

Title: Students can be charged with a felony for threatening violence under Tennessee laws
Description: Students threatening mass violence at school can be charged with a felony, under new laws in Tennessee. This has put law enforcement at odds with school officials.

Title: 2024 brought more dramatic changes in abortion rights across the U.S.
Description: It's been more than two years since the Supreme Court overturned a federal right to abortion and gave the issue to the states. 2025 could be the year states start battling each other in court.

Title: What would it mean for the U.S. to end birthright citizenship?
Description: NPR's Michel Martin talks about birthright citizenship with Julia Gelatt of the Migration Policy Institute.

Title: Biden administration rule aims to better protect miners
Description: A new Biden administration rule aims to better protect miners and taxpayers by reforming liability requirements for mining companies.

Title: Some U.S. cities see increase in marriages before start of Trump administration
Description: Some U.S. cities are seeing a bump in marriage licenses. Same-sex couples and couples with mixed immigration status are among those heading to the altar before the start of the Trump administration.

Title: Protests erupt in Alawite-minority areas of Syria
Description: Protests erupted in Syria in areas dominated by the Alawite minority after video spread of militants desecrating an Alawite shrine. Alawites are widely seen as loyal to the former Assad regime.

Title: A Tour of Gaza's Ancient Sites, Now Lost to War (Encore)
Description: Among the vast destruction of buildings in Gaza, some historically valuable and irreplaceable sites are now in ruins. In a story we first brought you in February, our correspondent visited some of these places before the war and brings us to them, then and now. Click here to see photos of some of the places referenced in this story.

Title: Mega Millions jackpot surges past $1 billion
Description: The Mega Millions prize has now grown to an estimated $1.15 billion, which could be the fifth-largest jackpot in the game's history. (Image credit: Scott Olson)

Title: The carjacking rate has started to drop after a disturbing jump in previous years
Description: Crime has been dropping, nationally -- but car jackings remain higher than before the pandemic. A new study analyzes the data on this crime, which may have finally peaked in 2024.

Title: The bald eagle officially becomes the U.S. bird
Description: It wasn't until this week that Congress passed a law making the bald eagle the official U.S. bird. And one man spearheaded the effort to get this done.

Title: Pope urges 'all people of all nations' to silence arms in Christmas address
Description: Pope Francis in his traditional Christmas message urged 'all people of all nations' to find courage 'to silence the sounds of arms and overcome divisions' plaguing the world, from the Middle East to Ukraine, Africa to Asia. (Image credit: Andrew Medichini)

Title: A gang attack on a Haitian hospital reopening kills 2 reporters and a police officer
Description: Street gangs forced the General Hospital in Port-au-Prince to close earlier this year. As journalists gathered to cover its reopening, suspected gang members opened fire. (Image credit: Odelyn Joseph)

Title: Far from the front lines, Ukrainians fight a war to preserve their culture
Description: In the Transcarpathia region, some locals embrace a traditional lifestyle and cultural identity. After surviving Soviet threats, now they fear President Vladimir Putin seeks to erase their culture. (Image credit: Claire Harbage)

Title: Russia targets Ukrainian energy infrastructure on Christmas Day
Description: Russia's massive missile and drone barrage struck a thermal power plant and prompted Ukrainians to shelter in metro stations on Christmas morning. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Christmas Day in Bethlehem -- the mood in the city is somber
Description: It's another Christmas in Bethlehem with the war still raging in Gaza. Palestinians in the city believed to be the birthplace of Jesus are hurting after more than a year of war.

Title: Longtime captain's retirement begins a new chapter for a West Virginia ferry ride
Description: The longtime pilot of the only Ohio River ferry in West Virginia is retiring. We'll take a ride with him.

Title: The Bachelor,' Ukraine edition, features a veteran who lost both legs in the war
Description: He wants to give hope to the tens of thousands of Ukrainians who have lost limbs since Russia's 2022 invasion of Ukraine. (Image credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for NPR)

Title: Holiday trivia: Do you know your ho ho ho?
Description: NPR's A Martinez and Steve Inskeep answer holiday trivia questions from 'Southern Living Magazine' senior editor Betsy Cribb Watson.

Title: Why some Christians in Syria fear the rebel group working to rebuild the country
Description: In Syria, some Christians aren't decorating their homes or putting up Christmas trees because they fear retaliation from rebels.

Title: Why some Christians fear the rebel group working to rebuild the country
Description: In Syria, some Christians aren't decorating their homes or putting up Christmas trees because they fear retaliation from rebels.

Title: Hundreds of giant nutcrackers help to revive an Ohio city's downtown
Description: Community leaders in Stubenville, Ohio, celebrate the holidays by decorating main street with hundreds of giant nutcrackers. The Christmas attraction is helping to bring the downtown back to life.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: It's another Christmas in Bethlehem with the war raging in Gaza. The severity of Sudan's famine has worsened. A review of what happened this year in space -- from an eclipse to minor malfunctions.

Title: Azerbaijan Airlines passenger jet crashes in the Kazakhstani city of Aktau
Description: An Azerbaijani airliner has crashed in the Kazakhstani city of Aktau with 30 people likely dead and at least 28 survivors, according to Kazakhstan's Emergency Ministry. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Norway's Salmon Farming Dilemma (Encore)
Description: Norway is the largest exporter of salmon in the world. And while some of those fish are wild-caught, many are raised in 'fish farms'- large cylindrical pens made of nylon in the open water. Sometimes these farmed fish escape, mixing with the local population and causing ecological issues. In a story we first brought you in October, we see farmed fish in a Norwegian fjord and hear about potential solutions to the problem. (Image credit: Rob Schmitz)

Title: He was shot in Vermont. Now he wants to go home to the West Bank
Description: Shot and severely injured while visiting family in Vermont in 2023, Hisham Awartani grapples with his recovery in the U.S., and the unfolding war at home in the West Bank.

Title: After 35 years, Sister Mary is leaving Project HOME, but continuing her mission
Description: NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with Sister Mary Scullion, the co-founder, executive director and president of Project H.O.M.E. about stepping down after 35 years at the organization she co-founded.

Title: The Assad regime's fall has freed displaced Syrians stuck in a remote desert camp
Description: More than 7,000 people had taken shelter in the Rukban camp, near the border with Jordan, many of whom fled the regime and ISIS attacks almost a decade ago. (Image credit: Manu Brabo for NPR)

Title: Starbucks baristas' 'strike before Christmas' has reached hundreds of U.S. stores
Description: Starbucks' union says workers are walking off the job at some 300 — out of over 10,000 — stores across the U.S. as contract negotiations falter. The company urges it to return to the bargaining table. (Image credit: Frederic J. Brown)

Title: American Airlines lifts ground stop that froze Christmas Eve travelers
Description: American Airlines passengers across the U.S. endured a sudden disruption of service on Christmas Eve as a 'technical issue' forced the airline to request a nationwide ground stop of its operations. (Image credit: Kamil Krzacznski)

Title: H-1B visas face uncertainty during Trump's 2nd term. And, the perfect mashed potatoes
Description: Foreign-born scientists may face challenges working in the U.S. during President-elect Donald Trump's second term. And, cooking tips for the perfect mashed potatoes this holiday. (Image credit: Justin Lane)
